title: What counts as evidence?
prompt: What would you accept as good evidence, and why?

title: Belief vs knowledge
prompt: How do you tell the difference between believing and knowing?

title: Certainty and doubt
prompt: When is doubt a strength—and when is it avoidance?

title: Authority check
prompt: When should you trust experts, and when should you question them?

title: A claim you heard
prompt: Pick a claim you’ve heard recently. What would verify it?

title: Changing your mind
prompt: What would have to happen for you to change your mind on something important?

title: Is confidence a signal of truth?
prompt: Is confidence a reliable signal of truth? Why or why not?

title: Spot the assumption
prompt: Identify one assumption in your first reaction to a topic.

title: Steelman first
prompt: Can you state the strongest version of the opposing view?

title: Correlation vs causation
prompt: When do we confuse correlation with causation?

title: Why arguments feel true
prompt: Why do some arguments feel convincing even when they’re wrong?

title: Second-order effects
prompt: What might happen after the thing you want happens?

title: Emotions and reasoning
prompt: When do emotions improve thinking, and when do they distort it?

title: Identity attachment
prompt: What belief feels like part of who you are—and why?

title: Overthinking vs planning
prompt: How do you tell overthinking from careful planning?

title: Self-deception
prompt: How can you tell when you’re rationalizing?

title: Confidence calibration
prompt: Where are you overconfident or underconfident?

title: Habit loop
prompt: What small habit would most improve your thinking?

title: Quick lens check
prompt: What does Literature & Wisdom help you notice that others miss?

title: Tradeoff practice
prompt: Name one tradeoff in a decision you’re facing.

title: Strongest opposite view
prompt: What’s the strongest opposing perspective—and what makes it strong?

title: Context shift
prompt: How might this look different in another context or culture?

title: Evidence vs values
prompt: What parts are facts, and what parts are values?

title: One good question
prompt: What’s one question that would clarify this the most?
